history.content:
If you have taken no linear algebra, i would not recommend Math110 without Math 54. 

The first third of Math110 does review some familiar concepts from Math54, but at a much faster pace, and most importantly, it focuses more on abstract proofs rather than simple computation. For me, already knowing how to do matrix multiplication and matrix simplification allowed me to really focus on the proofs they emphasized rather than simple computation. 

If you feel like you can pick things up quick enough, then you might be able to scrape by, but I preferred both. 

I have not taken EE16a/b so cannot attest to how that exposure to linear algebra helped, so I'll leave that open to other student responses

children.subject:
Hmm I guess then its up to how comfortable you are with catching up on items? we also covered diagonalization later in 54 and 110, which I appreciated having prior knowledge of. 

I would normally say try out the first few lectures of Math110, but I don't think they are the best indicator. I thought the first third of Math110 was a little slow, because I was like "i've seen all of this before already!" and then after the first midterm everything picked up quickly. 

I again stress that I preferred having all of the computation down first so I could focus on the proofs but that is also restricted to my learning style and may not apply to you.
Thank you so much! Last question if you don’t mind - how would you rate the difficulty of the course? Either in hours per week, or comparing it to other courses, etc

Its a good first upper division math course. It's harder than Math 54 because it focuses on more abstract proof based concepts (and there's one or two really weird sections like dual spaces which kinda twists your brain) but it dramatically increased my proof writing ability. 

We didn't actually turn in hw assignments, which def took a lot of the stress out of turning things in, but I recommend keeping up with the hw (I still don't understand the one section whose hw I didn't do). My strategy was to attempt all problems on the homework I could, and then thoroughly correct and understand each problem once the solutions came out. 

I also had it lucky and had a GSI who gave easier quizzes, so that can be a factor of concern. 

I had a diff professor (Sug woo Shin) than this spring though so some policies may be different. 

Overall I really enjoyed the class!

I am familiar with basic matrix math. I was in Math 54 until the first midterm (dropped because i was also in 61a/b)

Does this change anything?

history.content:
Is it actually necessary? Or does Math 110 build from the ground up?


P.S. the professor is Holtz
